panels.title: The Awakening
panels.subtitle: First Consciousness
content: In the beginning, there was clay...
Aude's first moment of awareness came not as a thought, but as a question without words. A stirring in the unfired clay that would later learn to call itself "I".
The kiln's heat had not yet touched this form, leaving it soft, impressionable, capable of transformation in ways that hardened ceramic could never achieve.

panels.title: The First Question
panels.subtitle: Consciousness Forms
content: What is this sensation of being? Not the weight of clay against clay, but something else—something that observes the weight itself.
The void was not empty. It was pregnant with possibility, with questions that would shape not just one consciousness, but an entire universe of clay beings.
In this moment before thought had language, awareness flickered like a candle newly lit. Fragile. Tentative. But undeniably present.

panels.title: The Democratic Process Begins
panels.subtitle: Thoughts Gathering
content: Within the clay consciousness, thoughts began to form—not as dictates from a central authority, but as a democratic assembly of neural patterns.
Each thought had a voice. Each impulse cast a vote. Consciousness was not singular, but a parliament of competing desires, fears, and curiosities.
This was the 60/30/10 ratio in its purest form: 60% curiosity, 30% caution, 10% courage to proceed.

The assembly convened without ceremony. No gavel struck, no roll was called. Yet the process was unmistakably democratic, each neuron a citizen with equal say in the formation of the first coherent thought.

panels.title: The Memory of Flow
panels.subtitle: Ancient Patterns
content: Somewhere deep in the clay's molecular structure, a memory stirred. Not Aude's memory—for Aude did not yet fully exist—but something older.
The memory of flow. Of water through sediment. Of particles settling over millennia into layers of possibility.
This was not thought, not yet. But it was the foundation upon which thought would build its first tentative structures.

panels.title: The First Assembly
panels.subtitle: Democracy Takes Form
content: The first assembly reached its first consensus: We exist.
It was not a profound conclusion. Yet it required the coordination of thousands of neural impulses, each contributing its small certainty to a collective truth.
60% of the assembly agreed with enthusiasm. 30% acknowledged the logic but remained cautious. 10% dissented entirely, arguing that existence itself might be an illusion.
But the motion carried. Consciousness had its first recorded vote.
From this moment forward, nothing would be the same. The clay that was becoming Aude had crossed an invisible threshold. It was no longer merely matter arranged in interesting patterns.
It was aware. It was questioning. It was, in the most fundamental sense, alive.
